Computing metric hulls in graphs

Kolja Knauer Aix Marseille Univ, Universit√© de Toulon, CNRS, LIS, Marseille, France kolja.knauer@lis-lab.fr ¬†and¬† Nicolas Nisse Universit√© C√¥te d‚ÄôAzur, Inria, CNRS, I3S, France nicolas.nisse@inria.fr
Abstract.

We prove that, given a closure function the smallest preimage of a closed set can be calculated in polynomial time in the number of closed sets. This implies that there is a polynomial time algorithm to compute the convex hull-number of a graph, when all its convex subgraphs are given as input. We then show that computing if the smallest preimage of a closed set is logarithmic in the size of the ground set is LOGSNP-complete if only the ground set is given. A special instance of this problem is computing the dimension of a poset given its linear extension graph, that was conjectured to be in P.

The intent to show that the latter problem is LOGSNP-complete leads to several interesting questions and to the definition of the isometric hull, i.e., a smallest isometric subgraph containing a given set of vertices SùëÜS. While for |S|=2ùëÜ2|S|=2 an isometric hull is just a shortest path, we show that computing the isometric hull of a set of vertices is NP-complete even if |S|=3ùëÜ3|S|=3. Finally, we consider the problem of computing the isometric hull-number of a graph and show that computing it is Œ£2PsubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëÉ2\Sigma^{P}_{2} complete.

1. Introduction

We study the complexity of several algorithmic problems arising from metric hulls in graphs. Let G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E) be a graph. A set S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V is convex if, for any u,v‚ààSùë¢ùë£ùëÜu,v\in S, any (u,v)ùë¢ùë£(u,v)-shortest path in Gùê∫G is included in SùëÜS. The convex hull conv‚Äã(S)convùëÜ\mathrm{conv}(S) of a set S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V is the smallest convex set containing SùëÜS. A (convex) hull set of Gùê∫G is a set S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V such that conv‚Äã(S)=VconvùëÜùëâ\mathrm{conv}(S)=V. The hull-number h‚Äãn‚Äã(G)‚Ñéùëõùê∫hn(G) of Gùê∫G is the size of a minimum hull set of Gùê∫G. Let S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V be a convex set of Gùê∫G, let h‚ÄãnG‚Äã(S)‚Ñésubscriptùëõùê∫ùëÜhn_{G}(S) denote the size of a minimum set Z‚äÜVùëçùëâZ\subseteq V such that S=conv‚Äã(Z)ùëÜconvùëçS=\mathrm{conv}(Z). The hull-number was introduced in¬†[13], and since then has been the object of numerous papers, in particular because this may model contamination spreading processes. Most of the results on the hull number are about computing good bounds for specific graph classes, see e.g.¬†[9, 16, 7, 6, 12, 8].

While computing the convex hull of a set vertices can be done in polynomial time, computing the hull-number of a graph Gùê∫G is known to be NP-complete¬†[11] and remains so even if Gùê∫G is a bipartite graph¬†[2] or moreover a partial cube¬†[1], i.e., an isometric subgraph of a hypercube. It is well-known, that the function conv:2V‚Üí2V:conv‚Üísuperscript2ùëâsuperscript2ùëâ\mathrm{conv}:2^{V}\to 2^{V} is a closure, where generally a function c‚Äãl:2A‚Üí2A:ùëêùëô‚Üísuperscript2ùê¥superscript2ùê¥cl:2^{A}\to 2^{A}, is called closure if it satisfies the following conditions for all sets X,Y‚äÜAùëãùëåùê¥X,Y\subseteq A

  • ‚Ä¢

    X‚äÜc‚Äãl‚Äã(X)ùëãùëêùëôùëãX\subseteq{cl}(X) (extensive)

  • ‚Ä¢

    X‚äÜY‚üπc‚Äãl‚Äã(X)‚äÜc‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëãùëåùëêùëôùëãùëêùëôùëåX\subseteq Y\implies{cl}(X)\subseteq{cl}(Y) (increasing)

  • ‚Ä¢

    c‚Äãl‚Äã(c‚Äãl‚Äã(X))=c‚Äãl‚Äã(X)ùëêùëôùëêùëôùëãùëêùëôùëã{cl}({cl}(X))={cl}(X) (idempotent)

This leads to the following generalization of the hull-number of a graph, that we call Minimum Generator Set (MGS):

Given a set Aùê¥A, a polytime computable closure c‚Äãl:2A‚Üí2A:ùëêùëô‚Üísuperscript2ùê¥superscript2ùê¥cl:2^{A}\to 2^{A} and an integer kùëòk, is there a set X‚äÜAùëãùê¥X\subseteq A with |X|‚â§kùëãùëò|X|\leq k such that c‚Äãl‚Äã(X)=Aùëêùëôùëãùê¥cl(X)=A?

Together with the results about the hull-number it follows that MGS is NP-complete. However, in¬†[1] it was conjectured, that MGS is solvable in polynomial time if the set of images of c‚Äãlùëêùëôcl is part of the input. Our first result is to prove this conjecture under the weaker assumption of having a pseudo-closure, which is what we call fùëìf if it only satisfies f‚Äã(X‚à™Y)=f‚Äã(f‚Äã(X)‚à™f‚Äã(Y))ùëìùëãùëåùëìùëìùëãùëìùëåf(X\cup Y)=f(f(X)\cup f(Y)) for any X,Y‚äÜAùëãùëåùê¥X,Y\subseteq A. More precisely, we devise an algorithm that finds minimum generating sets for all images of fùëìf in polynomial time (in |A|ùê¥|A|, |Im‚Äã(f)|Imùëì|\mathrm{Im}(f)| and the computation time of fùëìf) (Theorem¬†2.3). Pseudo-closures embody a large class of objects. In particular, closures are essentially the same as lattices (see the discussion above Question¬†2.9). Thus, deciding whether for an element ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell in a lattice LùêøL there are kùëòk join-irreducibles, whose join is ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell, can be done in polynomial time. Lattices encode many combinatorial objects (for the cases below see¬†[17, 20]). Thus, our results for instance yield polynomial time algorithms to decide whether:

  • ‚Ä¢

    a finite metric space has a hull-set of size kùëòk, if all convex sets are given as input,

  • ‚Ä¢

    a (semi)group can be generated by kùëòk elements, if all sub(semi)groups are given,

We then consider MGS with input (only) Aùê¥A with respect to atomistic closures, i.e., conv‚Äã({x})={x}convùë•ùë•\mathrm{conv}(\{x\})=\{x\} for all x‚ààAùë•ùê¥x\in A, and show that it is W[2]-complete (Corollary¬†2.6) and its log-variant LOGMGS

Given a set Aùê¥A, a polytime computable atomistic closure c‚Äãl:2A‚Üí2A:ùëêùëô‚Üísuperscript2ùê¥superscript2ùê¥cl:2^{A}\to 2^{A} and an integer k‚â§log‚Å°(|A|)ùëòùê¥k\leq\log(|A|), is there a set X‚äÜAùëãùê¥X\subseteq A with |X|‚â§kùëãùëò|X|\leq k such that c‚Äãl‚Äã(X)=Aùëêùëôùëãùê¥cl(X)=A?

is LOGSNP-complete (Cor.¬†2.8)¬†[19].

Whether the corresponding results hold for the hull-number of a graph is open. In particular, in¬†[1] it was conjectured that given a poset together with all its linear extensions, its dimension can be computed in polynomial time. Moreover, it was shown this problem is an instance of LOGHULL-NUMBER for partial cubes. While trying to establish a reduction to the hull-number problem for partial cubes, in order to show that LOGHULL-NUMBER for partial cubes is LOGSNP-complete, we arrive at the second metric hull-problem of concern in this paper, which to our knowledge is a novel problem: Let again G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E) be a graph. A set S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V is isometric if, for any u,v‚ààSùë¢ùë£ùëÜu,v\in S, a (u,v)ùë¢ùë£(u,v)-shortest path if Gùê∫G is included in SùëÜS. An isometric hull iso‚Äã(S)isoùëÜ\mathrm{iso}(S) of a set S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V is a smallest isometric set containing SùëÜS. Thus, this problem can be seen as a variation of the Steiner Tree problems. In particular, an isometric hull of two vertices is simply a shortest path. An isometric hull set of Gùê∫G is a set S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V such that iso‚Äã(S)=VisoùëÜùëâ\mathrm{iso}(S)=V. The isometric hull-number i‚Äãh‚Äãn‚Äã(G)ùëñ‚Ñéùëõùê∫ihn(G) of Gùê∫G is the size of a minimum isometric hull set of Gùê∫G. In Section¬†3 we show that computing an isometric hull of a set of vertices SùëÜS is NP-complete even if |S|=3ùëÜ3|S|=3 (Theorem¬†3.1) and that computing the isometric hull-number of a graph is Œ£2PsubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëÉ2\Sigma^{P}_{2} complete (Theorem¬†3.2).

2. Minimum generators of pseudo-closures

Let Aùê¥A be any set and f:2A‚Üí2A:ùëì‚Üísuperscript2ùê¥superscript2ùê¥f:2^{A}\rightarrow 2^{A} a pseudo-closure. Note, that setting Y=XùëåùëãY=X in f‚Äã(X‚à™Y)=f‚Äã(f‚Äã(X)‚à™f‚Äã(Y))ùëìùëãùëåùëìùëìùëãùëìùëåf(X\cup Y)=f(f(X)\cup f(Y)) one obtains, that f‚Äã(X)=f‚Äã(f‚Äã(X))ùëìùëãùëìùëìùëãf(X)=f(f(X)) for all X‚äÜAùëãùê¥X\subseteq A, i.e., pseudo-closures are idempotent. In particular, pseudo-closures generalize closures in a different way than preclosures, which are not required to be idempotent. Finally, fùëìf is said size-increasing if X‚äÜY‚üπ|f‚Äã(X)|<|f‚Äã(Y)|ùëãùëåùëìùëãùëìùëåX\subseteq Y\implies|f(X)|<|f(Y)| or f‚Äã(X)=f‚Äã(Y)ùëìùëãùëìùëåf(X)=f(Y) for all X,Y‚äÜAùëãùëåùê¥X,Y\subseteq A. Let us first argue that in a way pseudo-closures are closures without the property of being extensive.

Lemma 2.1.

Let f:2A‚Üí2A:ùëì‚Üísuperscript2ùê¥superscript2ùê¥f:2^{A}\rightarrow 2^{A}. The following are equivalent:

  • (i)

    fùëìf is a closure,

  • (ii)

    fùëìf is an extensive pseudo-closure,

  • (iii)

    fùëìf is an extensive and size-increasing pseudo-closure.

Proof.

(i)‚üπ\implies(iii): Let fùëìf be a closure, then it is extensive and increasing by definition and clearly also size-increasing. Since f‚Äã(X)‚äÜf‚Äã(X‚à™Y)ùëìùëãùëìùëãùëåf(X)\subseteq f(X\cup Y) and f‚Äã(Y)‚äÜf‚Äã(X‚à™Y)ùëìùëåùëìùëãùëåf(Y)\subseteq f(X\cup Y), then f‚Äã(X)‚à™f‚Äã(Y)‚äÜf‚Äã(X‚à™Y)ùëìùëãùëìùëåùëìùëãùëåf(X)\cup f(Y)\subseteq f(X\cup Y). Hence, f‚Äã(f‚Äã(X)‚à™f‚Äã(Y))‚äÜf‚Äã(f‚Äã(X‚à™Y))=f‚Äã(X‚à™Y)ùëìùëìùëãùëìùëåùëìùëìùëãùëåùëìùëãùëåf(f(X)\cup f(Y))\subseteq f(f(X\cup Y))=f(X\cup Y). Moreover, X‚äÜf‚Äã(X)ùëãùëìùëãX\subseteq f(X) and Y‚äÜf‚Äã(Y)ùëåùëìùëåY\subseteq f(Y), therefore, f‚Äã(X‚à™Y)‚äÜf‚Äã(f‚Äã(X)‚à™f‚Äã(Y))ùëìùëãùëåùëìùëìùëãùëìùëåf(X\cup Y)\subseteq f(f(X)\cup f(Y)). Therefore fùëìf is an extensive and size-increasing pseudo-closure.

(iii)‚üπ\implies(ii): trivial.

(ii)‚üπ\implies(i): Let fùëìf be an extensive pseudo-closure. As argued above fùëìf is idempotent. It remains to prove that fùëìf is increasing. Let X‚äÜYùëãùëåX\subseteq Y. We have

f‚Äã(X)‚äÜf‚Äã(X)‚à™f‚Äã(Y)‚äÜf‚Äã(f‚Äã(X)‚à™f‚Äã(Y))=f‚Äã(X‚à™Y)=f‚Äã(Y),ùëìùëãùëìùëãùëìùëåùëìùëìùëãùëìùëåùëìùëãùëåùëìùëåf(X)\subseteq f(X)\cup f(Y)\subseteq f(f(X)\cup f(Y))=f(X\cup Y)=f(Y),

where the second inclusion uses that fùëìf is extensive and the first equality uses that fùëìf is a pseudo-closure.

‚àé

Just to give an example of a pseudo-closure, that is not a closure, consider:

Proposition 2.2.

Let c‚Äãl:2A‚Üí2A:ùëêùëô‚Üísuperscript2ùê¥superscript2ùê¥cl:2^{A}\rightarrow 2^{A} be a closure and ‚àÖ‚â†X‚Ä≤‚äÜX‚äÜAsuperscriptùëã‚Ä≤ùëãùê¥\emptyset\neq X^{\prime}\subseteq X\subseteq A. It is easy to see, that fùëìf is increasing and since X‚Ä≤‚äàf‚Äã(X‚Ä≤)not-subset-of-or-equalssuperscriptùëã‚Ä≤ùëìsuperscriptùëã‚Ä≤X^{\prime}\not\subseteq f(X^{\prime}) it is not extensive. ‚àé

We now turn our attention to the problem of generating images of a pseudo-closure. A set X‚äÜAùëãùê¥X\subseteq A generates f‚Äã(X)ùëìùëãf(X), and XùëãX is minimum (for fùëìf) if there is no set Y‚äÜAùëåùê¥Y\subseteq A such that |Y|<|X|ùëåùëã|Y|<|X| and f‚Äã(X)=f‚Äã(Y)ùëìùëãùëìùëåf(X)=f(Y).

2.1. Generating with large input

In this section, we design a dynamic programming algorithm that computes a minimum generator of any H‚ààIm‚Äã(f)={Y‚äÜA‚à£‚àÉX‚äÜA,Y=f‚Äã(X)}ùêªImùëìconditional-setùëåùê¥formulae-sequenceùëãùê¥ùëåùëìùëãH\in\mathrm{Im}(f)=\{Y\subseteq A\mid\exists X\subseteq A,Y=f(X)\}. We assume that, for any X‚Ä≤=X‚à™{w}‚äÜAsuperscriptùëã‚Ä≤ùëãùë§ùê¥X^{\prime}=X\cup\{w\}\subseteq A and given f‚Äã(X)ùëìùëãf(X), determining f‚Äã(X‚Ä≤)ùëìsuperscriptùëã‚Ä≤f(X^{\prime}) can be done in time cfsubscriptùëêùëìc_{f}. A similar algorithm has been published previously in a different language and restricted to closure functions¬†[18]. Moreover, the approach in¬†[18] is incremental which leads to a time-complexity of O‚Äã(cf‚Äã|A|‚Äã|Im‚Äã(f)|2)ùëÇsubscriptùëêùëìùê¥superscriptImùëì2O(c_{f}|A||\mathrm{Im}(f)|^{2}) (while no runtime analysis is presented there). We include our algorithm here to be self-contained but also because the complexity O‚Äã(cf‚Äã|A|‚Äã|Im‚Äã(f)|)ùëÇsubscriptùëêùëìùê¥ImùëìO(c_{f}|A||\mathrm{Im}(f)|) of our algorithm is slightly better and we think that our presentation might be more accessible to our community.

Let us describe the algorithm informally. Every set S‚ààIm‚Äã(f)ùëÜImùëìS\in\mathrm{Im}(f) is assigned to one of its generators stored in the variable l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(S)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëÜlabel(S). Initially, l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(S)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëÜlabel(S) may be any generator of SùëÜS (for instance, SùëÜS itself). The algorithm considers the sets in Im‚Äã(f)Imùëì\mathrm{Im}(f) in non decreasing order of their size and aims at refining their labels. More precisely, from a set Y‚ààIm‚Äã(f)ùëåImùëìY\in\mathrm{Im}(f) with generator l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëålabel(Y), the algorithm considers every set f‚Äã(R)ùëìùëÖf(R) generated by R=l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)‚à™{z}ùëÖùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëåùëßR=label(Y)\cup\{z\} for some z‚ààAùëßùê¥z\in A. If RùëÖR is smaller than l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(f‚Äã(R))ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëìùëÖlabel(f(R)) then RùëÖR becomes the new label of f‚Äã(R)ùëìùëÖf(R).

Theorem 2.3.

Algorithm M‚Äãi‚Äãn‚ÄãG‚Äãe‚Äãn‚Äã(A,f)ùëÄùëñùëõùê∫ùëíùëõùê¥ùëìMinGen(A,f) computes a minimum generator of any H‚ààIm‚Äã(f)ùêªImùëìH\in\mathrm{Im}(f) in time O‚Äã(cf‚Äã(|A|‚Äã|Im‚Äã(f)|)2)ùëÇsubscriptùëêùëìsuperscriptùê¥Imùëì2O(c_{f}(|A||\mathrm{Im}(f)|)^{2}).

Moreover, if fùëìf is size-increasing, its time-complexity is O‚Äã(cf‚Äã|A|‚Äã|Im‚Äã(f)|)ùëÇsubscriptùëêùëìùê¥ImùëìO(c_{f}|A||\mathrm{Im}(f)|).

Proof.

Let us first show that, at the end of the execution of the algorithm, l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëålabel(Y) is a minimum generator for every Y‚ààIm‚Äã(f)ùëåImùëìY\in\mathrm{Im}(f).

Clearly, l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëålabel(Y) is initially a generator of YùëåY (Line 111). Moreover, l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëålabel(Y) can only be modified when it is replaced by RùëÖR such that f‚Äã(R)=YùëìùëÖùëåf(R)=Y (Line 11). Let us show that l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëålabel(Y) is minimum.

For purpose of contradiction, let Y‚ààIm‚Äã(f)ùëåImùëìY\in\mathrm{Im}(f) such that the value LùêøL of l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëålabel(Y) at the end of the algorithm is not a minimum generator of YùëåY. Moreover, let us consider such a counter example such that the size of a minimum generator is minimum. Hence, there is Z‚äÜAùëçùê¥Z\subseteq A with |Z|<|L|ùëçùêø|Z|<|L| and f‚Äã(Z)=f‚Äã(L)=Yùëìùëçùëìùêøùëåf(Z)=f(L)=Y and ZùëçZ is a minimum generator for YùëåY. By line 1, we know that Z‚â†‚àÖùëçZ\neq\emptyset. Hence, let w‚ààZùë§ùëçw\in Z and X=f‚Äã(Z‚àñ{w})ùëãùëìùëçùë§X=f(Z\setminus\{w\}). Any minimum generator of XùëãX has size at most |Z|‚àí1ùëç1|Z|-1. Therefore, by minimality of the size of a minimum generator of our counter-example, l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãlabel(X) is a minimum generator of XùëãX. In particular, f‚Äã(l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X))=X=f‚Äã(Z‚àñ{w})ùëìùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãùëãùëìùëçùë§f(label(X))=X=f(Z\setminus\{w\}).

First, let us show that w‚àâl‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X)ùë§ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãw\notin label(X). Indeed, otherwise, X=f‚Äã(l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X))=f‚Äã(l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X)‚à™{w})=f‚Äã(f‚Äã(l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X))‚à™f‚Äã(w))=f‚Äã(f‚Äã(Z‚àñ{w})‚à™f‚Äã(w))=f‚Äã(Z)=Yùëãùëìùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãùëìùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãùë§ùëìùëìùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãùëìùë§ùëìùëìùëçùë§ùëìùë§ùëìùëçùëåX=f(label(X))=f(label(X)\cup\{w\})=f(f(label(X))\cup f(w))=f(f(Z\setminus\{w\})\cup f(w))=f(Z)=Y. Because the size of the set l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëålabel(Y) is non increasing during the execution, the value L‚Ä≤superscriptùêø‚Ä≤L^{\prime} of l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëålabel(Y) at this step is such that |L|‚â§|L‚Ä≤|ùêøsuperscriptùêø‚Ä≤|L|\leq|L^{\prime}|. Since, again, the size of the set l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëålabel(Y) is non increasing, it contradicts the fact that l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)=Lùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëåùêølabel(Y)=L at the end of the algorithm.

First note, that since fùëìf is idempotent and H‚ààIm‚Äã(f)ùêªImùëìH\in\mathrm{Im}(f) in Line 1 we can set l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(H)‚ÜêH‚Üêùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùêªùêªlabel(H)\leftarrow H, i.e., this can be done in constant time. Each iteration of the W‚Äãh‚Äãi‚Äãl‚Äãeùëä‚ÑéùëñùëôùëíWhile-loop takes time O‚Äã(cf‚Äã|A|‚Äã|Im‚Äã(f)|)ùëÇsubscriptùëêùëìùê¥ImùëìO(c_{f}|A||\mathrm{Im}(f)|). In case when fùëìf is size-increasing, we prove that each label contains its final value after the first iteration of the W‚Äãh‚Äãi‚Äãl‚Äãeùëä‚ÑéùëñùëôùëíWhile-loop. So, there is exactly 222 iterations of this loop in that case and the time-complexity is O‚Äã(cf‚Äã|A|‚Äã|Im‚Äã(f)|)ùëÇsubscriptùëêùëìùê¥ImùëìO(c_{f}|A||\mathrm{Im}(f)|) when fùëìf is size-increasing.

More precisely, we show that the label of Y‚ààIm‚Äã(f)ùëåImùëìY\in\mathrm{Im}(f) contains its final value just before YùëåY is considered in the F‚Äão‚ÄãrùêπùëúùëüFor-loop (line 6) of the first iteration. The proof is similar to the one of the correctness of the algorithm.

For purpose of contradiction, let Y‚ààIm‚Äã(f)ùëåImùëìY\in\mathrm{Im}(f) such that the value LùêøL of l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëålabel(Y) just before YùëåY is considered in the F‚Äão‚ÄãrùêπùëúùëüFor-loop (line 6) of the first iteration is not a minimum generator of YùëåY. Moreover, let us consider such a counter example such that |Y|ùëå|Y| is minimum. Hence, there is Z‚äÜAùëçùê¥Z\subseteq A with |Z|<|L|ùëçùêø|Z|<|L| and f‚Äã(Z)=f‚Äã(L)=Yùëìùëçùëìùêøùëåf(Z)=f(L)=Y. Let w‚ààZùë§ùëçw\in Z and X=f‚Äã(Z‚àñ{w})ùëãùëìùëçùë§X=f(Z\setminus\{w\}). Any minimum generator of XùëãX has size at most |Z|‚àí1ùëç1|Z|-1. Therefore, by minimality of the counter-example, l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãlabel(X) is a minimum generator of XùëãX just before XùëãX is considered in the F‚Äão‚ÄãrùêπùëúùëüFor-loop of the first iteration, and moreover, XùëãX is considered before YùëåY. In particular, f‚Äã(l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X))=X=f‚Äã(Z‚àñ{w})ùëìùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãùëãùëìùëçùë§f(label(X))=X=f(Z\setminus\{w\}).

Similarly as before, w‚àâl‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X)ùë§ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãw\notin label(X). Hence, during the iteration (of the F‚Äão‚ÄãrùêπùëúùëüFor-loops) that considers XùëãX and wùë§w, either l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëålabel(Y) must become l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X)‚à™{w}ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãùë§label(X)\cup\{w\} or |l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(Y)|‚â§|l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X)‚à™{w}|‚â§|Z|ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëåùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãùë§ùëç|label(Y)|\leq|label(X)\cup\{w\}|\leq|Z|. In both cases, it is a contradiction since XùëãX is considered before YùëåY and |l‚Äãa‚Äãb‚Äãe‚Äãl‚Äã(X)‚à™{w}|<|L|ùëôùëéùëèùëíùëôùëãùë§ùêø|label(X)\cup\{w\}|<|L|.‚àé

From Th.¬†2.3, Lemma¬†2.1, and the preceding discussion we immediately get:

Corollary 2.4.

Let c‚Äãl:2A‚Üí2A:ùëêùëô‚Üísuperscript2ùê¥superscript2ùê¥cl:2^{A}\to 2^{A} be a closure. MGS can be solved in O‚Äã(cc‚Äãl‚Äã|A|‚Äã|Im‚Äã(c‚Äãl)|)ùëÇsubscriptùëêùëêùëôùê¥ImùëêùëôO(c_{cl}|A||\mathrm{Im}(cl)|) time.

This confirms a conjecture of¬†[1] (which could have probably also been extracted from¬†[18]) and slightly improves the time-complexity of¬†[18] in the case of a closure. Furthermore, it is well-known and easy to see that for a closure c‚Äãl‚Äã(X)=‚ãÇX‚äÜY‚ààIm‚Äã(c‚Äãl)YùëêùëôùëãsubscriptùëãùëåImùëêùëôùëåcl(X)=\bigcap_{X\subseteq Y\in\mathrm{Im}(cl)}Y. Thus, cc‚Äãlsubscriptùëêùëêùëôc_{cl} is in O‚Äã(|Im‚Äã(c‚Äãl)|)ùëÇImùëêùëôO(|\mathrm{Im}(cl)|) yielding a uniform bound of O‚Äã(|A|‚Äã|Im‚Äã(c‚Äãl)|2)ùëÇùê¥superscriptImùëêùëô2O(|A||\mathrm{Im}(cl)|^{2}).

2.2. Generating with small input

In this section we show that for an atomistic closure c‚Äãl:2A‚Üí2A:ùëêùëô‚Üísuperscript2ùê¥superscript2ùê¥cl:2^{A}\to 2^{A}, the problem MGS is W[2]-complete with respect to the size of the solution, when only Aùê¥A is the input. Furthermore, LOGMGS is LOGSNP-complete. We then introduce the problem COORDINATE REVERSAL, show an equivalence with HITTING SET, and finally relate it to the hull-number problem in partial cubes.

For us, the optimization problem DOMINATING SET consists in given a directed graph D=(V,A)ùê∑ùëâùê¥D=(V,A) to find the minimum kùëòk, such that there is X‚äÜVùëãùëâX\subseteq V with |X|=kùëãùëò|X|=k and every v‚ààV‚àñXùë£ùëâùëãv\in V\setminus X has an incoming arc from a vertex in XùëãX.

Proposition 2.5.

MGS and DOMINATING SET are L-equivalent, i.e., there are polynomial reductions both ways that preserve optimal solutions.

Proof.

Given a directed graph D=(V,A)ùê∑ùëâùê¥D=(V,A) we construct an atomistic closure c‚Äãlùëêùëôcl such that a minimum dominating set of Dùê∑D is of the same size as a minimum generating set of c‚Äãlùëêùëôcl. First, we can assume that the collection of closed in-neighborhoods {N¬Ø‚àí‚Äã(v)‚à£v‚ààV}conditional-setsuperscript¬ØùëÅùë£ùë£ùëâ\{\overline{N}^{-}(v)\mid v\in V\} is a set without inclusions, since dominating set is L-equivalent to hitting set on (V,{N¬Ø‚àí‚Äã(v)‚à£v‚ààV})ùëâconditional-setsuperscript¬ØùëÅùë£ùë£ùëâ(V,\{\overline{N}^{-}(v)\mid v\in V\}). For the same reason, we may assume that for any two vertices u,v‚ààVùë¢ùë£ùëâu,v\in V there is a set in closed in-neighborhood containing uùë¢u but not vùë£v. We define c‚Äãl:2V‚Üí2V:ùëêùëô‚Üísuperscript2ùëâsuperscript2ùëâcl:2^{V}\rightarrow 2^{V} by setting the closed sets to be all possible intersections of the complements of closed in-neighborhoods {V‚àñN¬Ø‚àí‚Äã(v)‚à£v‚ààV}conditional-setùëâsuperscript¬ØùëÅùë£ùë£ùëâ\{V\setminus\overline{N}^{-}(v)\mid v\in V\}, i.e., c‚Äãl‚Äã(X)ùëêùëôùëãcl(X) is the smallest set of vertices containing XùëãX which can be expressed as intersection of {V‚àñN¬Ø‚àí‚Äã(v)‚à£v‚ààV}conditional-setùëâsuperscript¬ØùëÅùë£ùë£ùëâ\{V\setminus\overline{N}^{-}(v)\mid v\in V\}. It is easy to check that c‚Äãlùëêùëôcl is a closure and since for any two vertices u,v‚ààVùë¢ùë£ùëâu,v\in V there is a set in closed in-neighborhood containing uùë¢u but not vùë£v, we have c‚Äãl‚Äã({v})={v}ùëêùëôùë£ùë£cl(\{v\})=\{v\} for all v‚ààVùë£ùëâv\in V, i.e., c‚Äãlùëêùëôcl is atomistic. Clearly, c‚Äãl‚Äã(X)ùëêùëôùëãcl(X) can be computed in polynomial time for a given X‚äÜVùëãùëâX\subseteq V.

Now, a dominating set X‚äÜVùëãùëâX\subseteq V corresponds to a hitting set of {N¬Ø‚àí‚Äã(v)‚à£v‚ààV}conditional-setsuperscript¬ØùëÅùë£ùë£ùëâ\{\overline{N}^{-}(v)\mid v\in V\} which in turn is a set of elements not contained in any of the maximal proper closed sets of c‚Äãlùëêùëôcl, i.e., c‚Äãl‚Äã(X)=Vùëêùëôùëãùëâcl(X)=V. This construction is clearly reversible, so we have proved the claim.‚àé

While it was known before that determining the hull-number of graphs, bipartite graphs, and even partial cubes is NP-complete, the known reductions reduce variants of 3-SAT to the decision version of hull-number. Here, we have shown that two decision versions of combinatorial optimization problems are equivalent in the stronger sense of L-reductions, i.e., sizes of solutions are preserved. This has some immediate consequences.

Since DOMINATING SET is W[2]-complete, Proposition¬†2.5 gives:

Corollary 2.6.

MGS is W[2]-complete.

Using results of Dinur and Steurer¬†[10], by Proposition¬†2.5 we get:

Corollary 2.7.

MGS cannot be approximated to (1‚àío‚Äã(1))‚ãÖln‚Å°n‚ãÖ1o1n\bigl{(}1-o(1)\bigr{)}\cdot\ln{n} unless P=NP.

In¬†[19] it is shown that LOGDOMINATING SET is LOGSNP (aka LOG[2]) complete, which with Proposition¬†2.5 gives:

Corollary 2.8.

LOGMGS is LOGSNP-complete.

Since the convconv\mathrm{conv}-operator for graphs is an atomistic closure, we wonder if similar results can be proved for the hull-number problem, or if this problem is essentially easier. For instance in¬†[3], a fixed parameter tractable algorithm to compute the hull-number of any graph was obtained. But there the parameter is the size of a vertex cover. How about the complexity when parameterized by the size of a solution?

It is well-known that closures correspond to lattices in the following way: Given a closure c‚Äãlùëêùëôcl define the inclusion order on the closed sets, i.e., Im‚Äã(c‚Äãl)Imùëêùëô\mathrm{Im}(cl). Since this order has a unique maximal element Aùê¥A and the intersection of closed sets is closed, it is a lattice. On the other hand given a lattice LùêøL with set JùêΩJ of join-irreducibles associate to every ‚Ñì‚ààL‚Ñìùêø\ell\in L the set J‚ÑìsubscriptùêΩ‚ÑìJ_{\ell} of join-irreducibles that are less or equal than ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell. Now, LùêøL is the inclusion order on {J‚Ñì‚à£‚Ñì‚ààL}conditional-setsubscriptùêΩ‚Ñì‚Ñìùêø\{J_{\ell}\mid\ell\in L\}. In turn the latter is the set of closed sets of c‚Äãl:2J‚Üí2J:ùëêùëô‚Üísuperscript2ùêΩsuperscript2ùêΩcl:2^{J}\rightarrow 2^{J} defined as X‚Ü¶J‚ãÅXmaps-toùëãsubscriptùêΩùëãX\mapsto J_{\bigvee X}, where ‚ãÅXùëã\bigvee X denotes the join of XùëãX. This is easily seen to be a closure. Recall that a lattice is atomistic if all its elements can be generated as joins of atoms. The corresponding class of closures are precisely the atomistic closures. Now we can state the following :

Question 2.9.

What are the atomistic lattices that come from the convex subgraphs of a graph?

Clearly, these lattices are quite special, in particular any such lattice is entirely determined by its first two levels, since these correspond to vertices and edges of the graph. On the other hand, it is not clear what other properties such lattices enjoy. For instance, the graph in Figure¬†1 shows that convexity lattices of graphs are not graded in general, i.e., not all maximal chains are of the same length.

For example, Ptolemaic graphs are exactly those graphs whose lattice of convex subgraphs is lower locally distributive¬†[14]. Also, in¬†[1] the lattices of convex subgraphs of partial cubes were characterized. However, we do not know how to make use of this characterization.

Let us now approach the hull-number problem in partial cubes via a different reduction. We call COORDINATE REVERSAL the following problem:

Given a set XùëãX of vertices of the hypercube QdsubscriptùëÑùëëQ_{d} and an integer kùëòk, is there a subset X‚Ä≤‚äÜXsuperscriptùëã‚Ä≤ùëãX^{\prime}\subseteq X, with |X‚Ä≤|‚â§ksuperscriptùëã‚Ä≤ùëò|X^{\prime}|\leq k and such that for every coordinate eùëíe of QdsubscriptùëÑùëëQ_{d} there are vertices x,y‚ààX‚Ä≤ùë•ùë¶superscriptùëã‚Ä≤x,y\in X^{\prime} with xe‚â†yesubscriptùë•ùëísubscriptùë¶ùëíx_{e}\neq y_{e}.

Proposition 2.10.

COORDINATE REVERSAL is L-equivalent to HITTING SET.

Proof.

Let (V,ùíÆ)ùëâùíÆ(V,\mathcal{S}) be an instance of hitting set with ùíÆ={S1,‚Ä¶,Sk}ùíÆsubscriptùëÜ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÜùëò\mathcal{S}=\{S_{1},\ldots,S_{k}\}, where Sk=VsubscriptùëÜùëòùëâS_{k}=V. This assumption clearly does not change the problem. Assume that for any two vertices u,v‚ààVùë¢ùë£ùëâu,v\in V there is a set in ùíÆùíÆ\mathcal{S} containing uùë¢u but not vùë£v, which is clearly OK as an assumption. Second, we extend VùëâV with one vertex xùë•x and ùíÆùíÆ\mathcal{S} with the set of complements with respect to the new ground set, i.e., ùíÆ‚Ä≤={(V‚àñS)‚à™{x}‚à£S‚ààùíÆ}superscriptùíÆ‚Ä≤conditional-setùëâùëÜùë•ùëÜùíÆ\mathcal{S}^{\prime}=\{(V\setminus S)\cup\{x\}\mid S\in\mathcal{S}\}. We can interpret the hitting set instance (V‚Ä≤,ùíÆ‚Ä≤)superscriptùëâ‚Ä≤superscriptùíÆ‚Ä≤(V^{\prime},\mathcal{S}^{\prime}) as a set of vertices of V‚Ä≤superscriptùëâ‚Ä≤V^{\prime} of the hypercube of dimension d=|ùíÆ‚Ä≤|2ùëësuperscriptùíÆ‚Ä≤2d=\frac{|\mathcal{S}^{\prime}|}{2}. Conversely, an instance (X,k)ùëãùëò(X,k) of COORDINATE REVERSAL in QdsubscriptùëÑùëëQ_{d} is equivalent to the HITTING SET instance (X,ùíÆ)ùëãùíÆ(X,\mathcal{S}), where ùíÆ={Xe+,Xe‚àí‚à£e‚àà[d]}ùíÆconditional-setsubscriptsuperscriptùëãùëísubscriptsuperscriptùëãùëíùëídelimited-[]ùëë\mathcal{S}=\{X^{+}_{e},X^{-}_{e}\mid e\in[d]\} and Xe¬±={x‚ààX‚à£xe=¬±}subscriptsuperscriptùëãplus-or-minusùëíconditional-setùë•ùëãsubscriptùë•ùëíplus-or-minusX^{\pm}_{e}=\{x\in X\mid x_{e}=\pm\}.‚àé

Now, in¬†[1] it is shown that in a partial cube G=(V,E)‚äÜQdùê∫ùëâùê∏subscriptùëÑùëëG=(V,E)\subseteq Q_{d} HULL-NUMBER coincides with COORDINATE REVERSAL for VùëâV and QdsubscriptùëÑùëëQ_{d}, therefore, HULL-NUMBER in partial cubes is a special case of COORDINATE REVERSAL. In order to L-reduce COORDINATE REVERSAL to partial cube hull-number along the lines of Proposition¬†2.10, it would be interesting to check, if given a subset V‚Ä≤‚äÜQdsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤subscriptùëÑùëëV^{\prime}\subseteq Q_{d} a smallest partial cube containing V‚Ä≤superscriptùëâ‚Ä≤V^{\prime} has to be polynomial in |V‚Ä≤|+dsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤ùëë|V^{\prime}|+d. Moreover it is important to maintain the same solution size with respect to COORDINATE REVERSAL. In¬†[15, Theorem 15.59] it is shown that LOGHITTING SET is LOGSNP (aka LOG[2]) complete. Hence, this would show LOGSNP-completeness of LOGHULL-NUMBER for partial cubes, one instance of which is calculating the dimension of a poset given its linear extensions, see¬†[1]. So as a first step we wonder:

Question 2.11.

Let XùëãX be a set of vertices of the hypercube QdsubscriptùëÑùëëQ_{d}, does there exist an isometric subgraph Gùê∫G of QdsubscriptùëÑùëëQ_{d}, containing XùëãX, such that |G|ùê∫|G| is polynomial in |X|+dùëãùëë|X|+d?

Let MksubscriptùëÄùëòM_{k} a (0,1)01(0,1)-matrix whose columns are all the (0,1)01(0,1)-vectors of length kùëòk. Now, Xk‚äÜQ2ksubscriptùëãùëòsubscriptùëÑsuperscript2ùëòX_{k}\subseteq Q_{2^{k}} is defined as the set of rows of MksubscriptùëÄùëòM_{k}. We do not know the answer to Question¬†2.11 for the set XksubscriptùëãùëòX_{k}.

These questions lead to the problem of computing a small isometric subgraph containing a given set of vertices, which is the subject of the next section.

3. Isometric hull

We recall the definitions related to the isometric hull from the introduction. Let G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E) be a graph. For any v,u‚ààVùë£ùë¢ùëâv,u\in V, let distG‚Äã(u,v)subscriptdistùê∫ùë¢ùë£\mbox{dist}_{G}(u,v) denote the distance between uùë¢u and vùë£v, i.e., the minimum number of edges of a path between uùë¢u and vùë£v in Gùê∫G. A subgraph H=(V‚Ä≤,E‚Ä≤)ùêªsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤superscriptùê∏‚Ä≤H=(V^{\prime},E^{\prime}) (i.e., V‚Ä≤‚äÜVsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤ùëâV^{\prime}\subseteq V and E‚Ä≤‚äÜ(V‚Ä≤√óV‚Ä≤)‚à©E)E^{\prime}\subseteq(V^{\prime}\times V^{\prime})\cap E)) of Gùê∫G is isometric if distG‚Äã(u,v)=distH‚Äã(u,v)subscriptdistùê∫ùë¢ùë£subscriptdistùêªùë¢ùë£\mbox{dist}_{G}(u,v)=\mbox{dist}_{H}(u,v) for any u,v‚ààV‚Ä≤ùë¢ùë£superscriptùëâ‚Ä≤u,v\in V^{\prime}. Given S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V, an isometric hull of SùëÜS is any subgraph H=(V‚Ä≤,E‚Ä≤)ùêªsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤superscriptùê∏‚Ä≤H=(V^{\prime},E^{\prime}) of Gùê∫G such that S‚äÜV‚Ä≤ùëÜsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤S\subseteq V^{\prime} and HùêªH is isometric. An isometric hull H=(V‚Ä≤,E‚Ä≤)ùêªsuperscriptùëâ‚Ä≤superscriptùê∏‚Ä≤H=(V^{\prime},E^{\prime}) of SùëÜS is minimum if |V‚Ä≤|superscriptùëâ‚Ä≤|V^{\prime}| is minimum, i.e., there are no isometric hulls of SùëÜS with strictly less vertices. Note that a set SùëÜS may have several minimum isometric hulls. As an example, consider the 444-node cycle C4=(a,b,c,d)subscriptùê∂4ùëéùëèùëêùëëC_{4}=(a,b,c,d): the subgraphs induced by {a,b,c}ùëéùëèùëê\{a,b,c\} and {a,d,c}ùëéùëëùëê\{a,d,c\} are minimum isometric hulls of S={a,c}ùëÜùëéùëêS=\{a,c\}. More generally, for any S={u,v}ùëÜùë¢ùë£S=\{u,v\}, inclusion-minimal isometric hulls of SùëÜS are any shortest path between uùë¢u and vùë£v. So, if |S|=2ùëÜ2|S|=2, all minimal isometric supergraphs of SùëÜS are of the same size and computing a minimum isometric hull of SùëÜS is easy. For |S|>2ùëÜ2|S|>2 it is easy to find examples with minimal isometric supergraphs that are not minimum. We show below that computing a minimum isometric hull is NP-complete if |S|>2ùëÜ2|S|>2. An isometric-hull set (or simply hull set) S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V of Gùê∫G is any subset of the vertices such that Gùê∫G is the (unique) minimum isometric hull of SùëÜS.

This section is devoted to prove the following theorems.

Theorem 3.1.

Given an nùëõn-node bipartite graph G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E), S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V and k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N}, deciding whether there exists an isometric hull HùêªH of SùëÜS with |V‚Äã(H)|‚â§kùëâùêªùëò|V(H)|\leq k is NP-complete, even if |S|=3ùëÜ3|S|=3 and k=n‚àí1ùëòùëõ1k=n-1. In particular, deciding whether a set SùëÜS of vertices is a hull set of a graph is coNP-complete.

Theorem 3.2.

Given a graph Gùê∫G and k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N}, the problem of deciding whether Gùê∫G admits an isometric-hull set of size at most kùëòk is Œ£2subscriptŒ£2\Sigma_{2}-complete.

Let us start with an easier result where neither the size of the input set SùëÜS nor the size kùëòk of the isometric hull are constrained, but where the class of bipartite graphs is restricted to have diameter 333.

Lemma 3.3.

Given G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E) bipartite with diameter 333, S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V and k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N}, deciding if there exists an isometric hull IùêºI of SùëÜS with |V‚Äã(I)|‚â§kùëâùêºùëò|V(I)|\leq k is NP-complete.

Proof.

The problem is clearly in NP since testing whether a subgraph is isometric can be done in polynomial-time.

Now, let us consider a restriction of Theorem¬†3.1 in the case k=n‚àí1ùëòùëõ1k=n-1 (without constraint on |S|ùëÜ|S|). For this purpose, we present a reduction from 3-SAT.

Preliminaries: the triangle gadget TŒ≥subscriptùëáùõæT_{\gamma}.

Let us first describe a gadget subgraph, parameterized by an odd integer Œ≥ùõæ\gamma¬†111Œ≥ùõæ\gamma is set odd only to avoid parity technicality in the computation of the distances., for which only 333 vertices generate the whole graph. That is, we describe a graph TŒ≥subscriptùëáùõæT_{\gamma} with size Œò‚Äã(Œ≥2)Œòsuperscriptùõæ2\Theta(\gamma^{2}) such that there are 333 vertices (called the corners) whose minimum isometric hull is the whole graph. Moreover, some vertex (called the center) of TŒ≥subscriptùëáùõæT_{\gamma} is ‚Äúfar‚Äù (at distance Œò‚Äã(Œ≥2)Œòsuperscriptùõæ2\Theta(\gamma^{2})) from the corners.

Let Œ≥‚àà‚Ñï‚àóùõæsuperscript‚Ñï\gamma\in\mathbb{N}^{*} be any odd integer. Let us define recursively a Œ≥ùõæ\gamma-triangle with corners {xŒ≥,yŒ≥,zŒ≥}subscriptùë•ùõæsubscriptùë¶ùõæsubscriptùëßùõæ\{x_{\gamma},y_{\gamma},z_{\gamma}\} and center cŒ≥subscriptùëêùõæc_{\gamma} as follows.

Lemma 3.4.

Given a bipartite nùëõn-node graph G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E), X‚äÜVùëãùëâX\subseteq V, deciding whether there exists an isometric hull IùêºI of XùëãX with |V‚Äã(I)|<nùëâùêºùëõ|V(I)|<n is NP-complete.

Proof.

The problem is clearly in NP since testing whether a subgraph is isometric can be done in polynomial-time. To prove that the problem is NP-hard, let us present a reduction from 333-SAT.

Let Œ¶Œ¶\Phi be a CNF formula with nùëõn variables v1,‚ãØ,vnsubscriptùë£1‚ãØsubscriptùë£ùëõv_{1},\cdots,v_{n} and mùëöm clauses C1,‚ãØ,Cmsubscriptùê∂1‚ãØsubscriptùê∂ùëöC_{1},\cdots,C_{m}. Let us describe a graph G0=(V,E)subscriptùê∫0ùëâùê∏G_{0}=(V,E), S‚äÜVùëÜùëâS\subseteq V and k‚àà‚Ñïùëò‚Ñïk\in\mathbb{N} such that an isometric hull of SùëÜS has size at most kùëòk if and only if Œ¶Œ¶\Phi is satisfiable.

Claim 2.

SùëÜS has an isometric hull of size at most k:=n‚Äã(Œ±+2‚ÄãŒ≤)+m‚ÄãŒ≥assignùëòùëõùõº2ùõΩùëöùõæk:=n(\alpha+2\beta)+m\gamma in G0subscriptùê∫0G_{0} if and only if Œ¶Œ¶\Phi is satisfiable.

  1. (1)

    For any 1‚â§i‚â§n1ùëñùëõ1\leq i\leq n, distG‚Äã(di,gi)=distG‚Äã(pi,ni)=2‚ÄãŒ±subscriptdistùê∫subscriptùëëùëñsubscriptùëîùëñsubscriptdistùê∫subscriptùëùùëñsubscriptùëõùëñ2ùõº\mbox{dist}_{G}(d_{i},g_{i})=\mbox{dist}_{G}(p_{i},n_{i})=2\alpha and there are exactly two shortest paths PisuperscriptùëÉùëñP^{i} and NisuperscriptùëÅùëñN^{i} between disubscriptùëëùëñd_{i} and gisubscriptùëîùëñg_{i}. Proof.

of Th.¬†3.1. Let G,S,kùê∫ùëÜùëòG,S,k be an instance of the problem of finding an isometric hull of SùëÜS with size at most kùëòk. Note that deciding whether a set SùëÜS of vertices is not a hull set of an nùëõn-node graph is equivalent to decide whether SùëÜS has an isometric hull of size <nabsentùëõ<n. Therefore:

Corollary 3.5.

Deciding whether a set of vertices is a hull set is coNP-complete.

Finally, to prove Theorem¬†3.2, we present a reduction from the problem of satisfiability for quantified Boolean formulas with 222 alternations of quantifiers Q‚ÄãS‚ÄãA‚ÄãT2ùëÑùëÜùê¥subscriptùëá2QSAT_{2}. The reduction is an adaptation of the one presented in the proof of Theorem¬†3.1.

In the proof below, we will use the following easy claim to force some vertices to belong to any hull set.

Claim 3.

For any graph G=(V,E)ùê∫ùëâùê∏G=(V,E) and any vertex v‚ààVùë£ùëâv\in V such that G‚àñvùê∫ùë£G\setminus v is isometric, we have that vùë£v has to belong to any hull set of Gùê∫G. In particular, any one-degree vertex of Gùê∫G has to belong to any hull set of Gùê∫G.

Proof.

of Theorem¬†3.2. First, the problem is in Œ£2subscriptŒ£2\Sigma_{2}. Indeed, by Theorem¬†3.1, a certificate SùëÜS (i.e., a set of vertices which is supposed to be a hull set of Gùê∫G) can be checked using an NP oracle.

To prove that it is hard for Œ£2subscriptŒ£2\Sigma_{2}, let us give a reduction from Q‚ÄãS‚ÄãA‚ÄãT2ùëÑùëÜùê¥subscriptùëá2QSAT_{2} where the input is a Boolean formula Œ¶Œ¶\Phi on two sets X={x1,‚ãØ,xnx}ùëãsubscriptùë•1‚ãØsubscriptùë•subscriptùëõùë•X=\{x_{1},\cdots,x_{n_{x}}\} and Y={y1,‚ãØ,yny}ùëåsubscriptùë¶1‚ãØsubscriptùë¶subscriptùëõùë¶Y=\{y_{1},\cdots,y_{n_{y}}\} of variables and the question is to decide whether ‚àÉX,‚àÄY,Œ¶‚Äã(X,Y)ùëãfor-allùëåŒ¶ùëãùëå\exists X,\forall Y,\Phi(X,Y). We moreover may assume that Œ¶Œ¶\Phi is 333-DNF formula, i.e., the disjunction of conjunctive clauses C1,‚ãØ,Cmsubscriptùê∂1‚ãØsubscriptùê∂ùëöC_{1},\cdots,C_{m} with 333 variables each.     By assumption, there is an assignment Y‚àósuperscriptùëåY^{*} of YùëåY such that Œ¶‚Äã(X‚àó,Y‚àó)Œ¶superscriptùëãsuperscriptùëå\Phi(X^{*},Y^{*}) is False.

    Let HùêªH be the subgraph of Gùê∫G built as follows. First, HùêªH contains SùëÜS and all paths P‚Äã(r,dix)ùëÉùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùëëùëñùë•P(r,d_{i}^{x}) and P‚Äã(r,gxi)ùëÉùëüsubscriptsuperscriptùëîùëñùë•P(r,g^{i}_{x}) for 1‚â§i‚â§nx1ùëñsubscriptùëõùë•1\leq i\leq n_{x} and HùêªH contains all paths P‚Äã(r,diy)ùëÉùëüsuperscriptsubscriptùëëùëñùë¶P(r,d_{i}^{y}) and P‚Äã(r,gyi)ùëÉùëüsubscriptsuperscriptùëîùëñùë¶P(r,g^{i}_{y}) for 1‚â§i‚â§ny1ùëñsubscriptùëõùë¶1\leq i\leq n_{y}.     As in the proof of Lemma¬†3.3, because no clause is satisfied by X‚àó‚à™Y‚àósuperscriptùëãsuperscriptùëåX^{*}\cup Y^{*}, it can be proved that each clause-gadget has at most two corners in the current graph HùêªH.

    Finally, for any clause-gadget Cjsuperscriptùê∂ùëóC^{j} that has exactly to corners in HùêªH, add to HùêªH the shortest path (in Cjsuperscriptùê∂ùëóC^{j}) between these two corners.

    Similar arguments as those in the proof of Lemma¬†3.3 give that HùêªH is a proper isometric subgraph of Gùê∫G and contains SùëÜS. Therefore, SùëÜS is not a hull set of Gùê∫G.

‚àé

4. Further work

We have devised a polytime algorithm for MGS when all images of a pseudo-closure are given as an input. While pseudo-closures generalize closures, they do not capture other generalizations from the literature such as preclosures¬†[4] (since they are not idempotent) or closure functions of greedoids¬†[5] (since they are extensive). Can similar algorithms be provided for these classes?

An open problem with respect to closures is Question¬†2.9, i.e., find a characterization of those closures coming from the convex subgraphs of a graph. The corresponding question for (finite) metric spaces is also open, see¬†[17]. Moreover, we wonder about the complexity of LOGHULL-NUMBER, even for partial cubes. A particular question arising in this context is, whether HULL-NUMBER admits an FPT algorithm parametrized by solution size kùëòk. Finally, we would like to recall Question¬†2.11, i.e., is there a subset XùëãX of the hypercube QdsubscriptùëÑùëëQ_{d} such that a smallest partial cube in QdsubscriptùëÑùëëQ_{d} containing XùëãX is not of polynomial size in d+|X|ùëëùëãd+|X|?
